feed.title: Spark NLP
feed.subtitle: High Performance NLP with Apache Spark

entry.title: Legal Adjustments Clause Binary Classifier
entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the adjustments clause type. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so itâ€™s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big legal documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Legal Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

This model can be combined with any of the other 200+ Legal Clauses Classifiers you will find in Models Hub, getting as an output a series of True/False values for each of the legal clause model you have added.

Predicted Entities

other, adjustments

Download

How to use

documentAssembler = DocumentAssembler() \
     .setInputCol("clause_text") \
     .setOutputCol("document")
  
embeddings = BertSentenceEmbeddings.pretrained("sent_bert_base_cased", "en") \
      .setInputCols("document") \
      .setOutputCol("sentence_embeddings")

docClassifier = ClassifierDLModel().pretrained("legal_sequence_classifier_adjustments_clause", "en", "legal/models")\
    .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\
    .setOutputCol("category")
    
nlpPipeline = Pipeline(stages=[
    documentAssembler, 
    embeddings,
    docClassifier])
 
df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("clause_text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)
result = model.transform(df)

Results

+-------+
| result|
+-------+
|[adjustments]|
|[other]|
|[other]|
|[adjustments]|

Model Information

Model Name: legal_sequence_classifier_adjustments_clause
Type: legal
Compatibility: Spark NLP for Legal 1.0.0+
License: Licensed
Edition: Official
Input Labels: [sentence_embeddings]
Output Labels: [category]
Language: en
Size: 22.8 MB

References

Propietary legal documents annotated in-house

Benchmarking

              precision    recall  f1-score   support

 adjustments       0.92      0.89      0.91        27
       other       0.96      0.97      0.96        69

    accuracy                           0.95        96
   macro avg       0.94      0.93      0.93        96
weighted avg       0.95      0.95      0.95        96
entry.summary: Description This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the adjustments clause type. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so itâ€™s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level. If you have big legal documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Legal Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely: Paragraph splitting (by multiline); Splitting by headers / subheaders; etc. Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above). This model can be combined with any of the other 200+ Legal Clauses Classifiers you will find in Models Hub, getting as an output a series of True/False values for each of the legal clause model you have added. Predicted Entities other, adjustments Live Demo Open in Colab Download How to use PythonScalaNLU documentAssembler = DocumentAssembler() \ .setInputCol("clause_text") \ .setOutputCol("document") embeddings = BertSentenceEmbeddings.pretrained("sent_bert_base_cased", "en") \ .setInputCols("document") \ .setOutputCol("sentence_embeddings") docClassifier = ClassifierDLModel().pretrained("legal_sequence_classifier_adjustments_clause", "en", "legal/models")\ .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\ .setOutputCol("category") nlpPipeline = Pipeline(stages=[ documentAssembler, embeddings, docClassifier]) df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("clause_text") model = nlpPipeline.fit(df) result = model.transform(df) Results +-------+ | result| +-------+ |[adjustments]| |[other]| |[other]| |[adjustments]| Model Information Model Name: legal_sequence_classifier_adjustments_clause Type: legal Compatibility: Spark NLP for Legal 1.0.0+ License: Licensed Edition: Official Input Labels: [sentence_embeddings] Output Labels: [category] Language: en Size: 22.8 MB References Propietary legal documents annotated in-house Benchmarking precision recall f1-score support adjustments 0.92 0.89 0.91 27 other 0.96 0.97 0.96 69 accuracy 0.95 96 macro avg 0.94 0.93 0.93 96 weighted avg 0.95 0.95 0.95 96

Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the approvals clause type. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so itâ€™s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big legal documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Legal Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

This model can be combined with any of the other 200+ Legal Clauses Classifiers you will find in Models Hub, getting as an output a series of True/False values for each of the legal clause model you have added.

entry.title: Legal Bereavement leave Clause Binary Classifier

link.title: Legal Bereavement leave Clause Binary Classifier

entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the bereavement-leave clause type. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so itâ€™s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big legal documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Legal Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

This model can be combined with any of the other 200+ Legal Clauses Classifiers you will find in Models Hub, getting as an output a series of True/False values for each of the legal clause model you have added.

Predicted Entities

other, bereavement-leave

Download

How to use

documentAssembler = DocumentAssembler() \
     .setInputCol("clause_text") \
     .setOutputCol("document")
  
embeddings = BertSentenceEmbeddings.pretrained("sent_bert_base_cased", "en") \
      .setInputCols("document") \
      .setOutputCol("sentence_embeddings")

docClassifier = ClassifierDLModel().pretrained("legal_sequence_classifier_bereavement_leave_clause", "en", "legal/models")\
    .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\
    .setOutputCol("category")
    
nlpPipeline = Pipeline(stages=[
    documentAssembler, 
    embeddings,
    docClassifier])
 
df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("clause_text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)
result = model.transform(df)

Results

+-------+
| result|
+-------+
|[bereavement-leave]|
|[other]|
|[other]|
|[bereavement-leave]|

References

bereavement-leave       1.00      1.00      1.00        30
            other       1.00      1.00      1.00        76

         accuracy                           1.00       106
        macro avg       1.00      1.00      1.00       106
     weighted avg       1.00      1.00      1.00       106

If you have big legal documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Legal Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely: Paragraph splitting (by multiline); Splitting by headers / subheaders; etc. Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. entry.title: Legal Change of control Clause Binary Classifier

link.title: Legal Change of control Clause Binary Classifier

entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the change-of-control clause type. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so itâ€™s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big legal documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Legal Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

This model can be combined with any of the other 200+ Legal Clauses Classifiers you will find in Models Hub, getting as an output a series of True/False values for each of the legal clause model you have added.

Predicted Entities

other, change-of-control

Download

How to use

     .setInputCol("clause_text") \
     .setOutputCol("document")

    .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\
    .setOutputCol("category")

    documentAssembler, 
    embeddings,
    docClassifier])
 
df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("clause_text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)
result = model.transform(df)

If you have big legal documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Legal Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely: Paragraph splitting (by multiline); Splitting by headers / subheaders; etc. Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above). This model can be combined with any of the other 200+ Legal Clauses Classifiers you will find in Models Hub, getting as an output a series of True/False values for each of the legal clause model you have added. Predicted Entities other, change-of-control Live Demo Open in Colab Download How to use PythonScalaNLU documentAssembler = DocumentAssembler() \ .setInputCol("clause_text") \ .setOutputCol("document") embeddings = BertSentenceEmbeddings.pretrained("sent_bert_base_cased", "en") \ .setInputCols("document") \ .setOutputCol("sentence_embeddings") docClassifier = ClassifierDLModel().pretrained("legal_sequence_classifier_change_of_control_clause", "en", "legal/models")\ .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\ .setOutputCol("category") nlpPipeline = Pipeline(stages=[ documentAssembler, embeddings, docClassifier]) df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("clause_text") model = nlpPipeline.fit(df) result = model.transform(df) Results +-------+ | result| +-------+ |[change-of-control]| |[other]| |[other]| |[change-of-control]| Model Information Model Name: legal_sequence_classifier_change_of_control_clause Type: legal Compatibility: Spark NLP for Legal 1.0.0+ License: Licensed Edition: Official Input Labels: [sentence_embeddings] Output Labels: [category] Language: en Size: 23.0 MB References Propietary legal documents annotated in-house Benchmarking precision recall f1-score support change-of-control 1.00 0.86 0.92 28 other 0.94 1.00 0.97 68 accuracy 0.96 96 macro avg 0.97 0.93 0.95 96 weighted avg 0.96 0.96 0.96 96

entry.title: Legal Compensation Clause Binary Classifier
entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the compensation clause type. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so itâ€™s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big legal documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Legal Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

This model can be combined with any of the other 200+ Legal Clauses Classifiers you will find in Models Hub, getting as an output a series of True/False values for each of the legal clause model you have added.

Predicted Entities

other, compensation

Download

How to use

documentAssembler = DocumentAssembler() \
     .setInputCol("clause_text") \
     .setOutputCol("document")
  
embeddings = BertSentenceEmbeddings.pretrained("sent_bert_base_cased", "en") \
      .setInputCols("document") \
      .setOutputCol("sentence_embeddings")

docClassifier = ClassifierDLModel().pretrained("legal_sequence_classifier_compensation_clause", "en", "legal/models")\
    .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\
    .setOutputCol("category")
    
nlpPipeline = Pipeline(stages=[
    documentAssembler, 
    embeddings,
    docClassifier])
 
df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("clause_text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)
result = model.transform(df)

Results

+-------+
| result|
+-------+
|[compensation]|
|[other]|
|[other]|
|[compensation]|

Model Information

Model Name: legal_sequence_classifier_compensation_clause
Type: legal
Compatibility: Spark NLP for Legal 1.0.0+
License: Licensed
Edition: Official
Input Labels: [sentence_embeddings]
Output Labels: [category]
Language: en
Size: 22.9 MB

References

Propietary legal documents annotated in-house

Benchmarking

              precision    recall  f1-score   support

compensation       0.94      0.88      0.91        34

    accuracy                           0.95       112
   macro avg       0.94      0.93      0.94       112
weighted avg       0.95      0.95      0.95       112

link.title: Legal Compliance with laws Clause Binary Classifier

entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the compliance-with-laws clause type. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so itâ€™s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big legal documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Legal Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).
